summary: **noun / packaging / audiophile.** A paper sleeve lined with smooth polyethylene.
definition: **noun / packaging / audiophile.** A paper sleeve lined with smooth polyethylene to reduce static and scuffing — the preferred archival inner. Introduced in the mid-1970s as an upgrade to plain paper sleeves, poly-lined inners feature a thin layer of high-density polyethylene (HDPE) bonded to paper stock, creating a slippery surface that minimizes friction during insertion and removal. The polyethylene layer dramatically reduces static buildup that attracts dust and prevents the paper fibers from abrading the vinyl surface, a common problem with standard paper sleeves. Mobile Fidelity Sound Lab (MoFi) popularized premium versions in the 1980s with their rice-paper/poly hybrids, setting the audiophile standard. Modern variants include round-bottom designs that protect record edges and anti-static formulations. While original pressings often shipped with generic paper sleeves, collectors routinely replace them with poly-lined alternatives to preserve record condition. Available in white paper/poly, kraft paper/poly, and rice paper/poly constructions, with prices ranging from $0.25 to $1.50 per sleeve. Essential for any serious collection, particularly valuable pressings where surface noise preservation is critical.
etymology: Compound term combining 'polyethylene' (thermoplastic polymer developed 1930s) with 'lined' and 'inner sleeve,' emerging as audiophile packaging innovation during 1970s vinyl quality movement.
